description: From Old English wolde, past tense of willan.

entries.meaning: Something that would happen, or would be the case, under different circumstances; a potentiality.

definitionGroups.group: Past tense of will; usually followed by a bare infinitive.

entries.meaning: Used to form the "anterior future", or "future in the past", indicating a futurity relative to a past time. [from 9th c.]
examples: On my first day at University, I met the woman who would become my wife.

entries.meaning: Used to; was or were habitually accustomed to; indicating an action in the past that happened repeatedly or commonly. [from 9th c.]
examples: When we were younger, we would cycle out to the beach most summer Sundays.

entries.meaning: Was or were determined to; indicating someone's insistence upon doing something. [from 18th c.]
examples: I asked her to stay in with me, but she would go out.

entries.meaning: Could naturally have been expected to (given the tendencies of someone's character etc.). [from 18th c.]
examples: He denied it, but then he would, wouldn't he?
The Greeks, especially those who would be thought adepts in mystic theology, ran after fantastic allegories […].

entries.meaning: (archaic) Used with ellipsis of the infinitive verb, or postponement to a relative clause, in various senses. [from 9th c.]
examples: At which time he told me, he would to London that week, and so to Oxford.

definitionGroups.group: A modal verb, the subjunctive of will; usually followed by a bare infinitive.

entries.meaning: Used as the auxiliary of the simple conditional modality, indicating a state or action that is conditional on another. [from 9th c.]
examples: If I won the lottery, I would give half the money to charity.

entries.meaning: Without explicit condition, or with loose or vague implied condition, indicating a hypothetical or imagined state or action.
examples: I would love to come and visit.
Look at that yummy cake! I would eat that all up!

entries.meaning: Suggesting conditionality or potentiality in order to express a sense of politeness, tentativeness, indirectness, hesitancy, uncertainty, etc. [from 9th c.]
examples: I would ask you all to sit down.
I would imagine that they have already left.

entries.meaning: Used to express what the speaker would do in another person's situation, as a means of giving a suggestion or recommendation.
examples: It's disgraceful the way that they've treated you. I would write and complain.

entries.meaning: Used to express the speaker's belief or assumption.
examples: He's very security-conscious, so he would have remembered to lock the door.
They would be arriving in London round about now.

entries.meaning: Used interrogatively to express a polite request; are (you) willing to …? [from 15th c.]
examples: Would you pass the salt, please?

entries.meaning: (chiefly archaic) Might wish (+ verb in past subjunctive); often used in the first person (with or without that) in the sense of "if only". [from 13th c.]
examples: But as the youth increased their annoyance by declaring that the goddess was quite right, because the Emperor was Archon Eponym of the city of Athens, he said: "Would that he also presided the Panathenaic festival."

entries.meaning: (chiefly archaic, transitive or control verb) Might desire; wish (something). [from 15th c.]
